title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act is titled the "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" and establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act mandates the development of protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with states, public health officers, and attorneys general in this process. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. Dangerous biological agents are those listed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 and not exempted from applicability. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. Dangerous chemicals are those listed under a developed list by the Secretary in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board. The Clean Air Act requires the development of a list of chemicals known or anticipated to cause serious adverse effects on human health, including those listed under section 112(r)(3) of the Act. These chemicals are considered candidates for use by individuals intending to cause harm. The Clean Air Act mandates the identification of chemicals with serious adverse effects on human health. Protocols for hazardous agents must be developed, tailored to each specific agent. Priorities and timeframes for response must be established by the Secretary within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must establish priorities among hazardous agents for protocol development within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Development of protocols should be completed within 45 days of starting the process. The Secretary must establish priorities for protocol development among hazardous agents within 45 days. Protocols should be developed promptly and ensure uniform application in public health emergencies involving the hazardous agent. Coordination with emergency response personnel is essential for uniformity. The Secretary must establish priorities for protocol development among hazardous agents within 45 days, ensuring uniform application in public health emergencies. This includes providing prompt medically appropriate information, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and responding differently based on the nature of the hazardous agent release. Additional provisions may be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary periodically reviews and revises protocols as needed. Development exemptions may apply if existing protocols meet requirements. A report listing exemptions must be submitted to Congress within 30 days of enactment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary to carry out the development exemptions for hazardous agents. Sums are authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2002 through 2006, in addition to other authorizations available for this purpose.
